bit: The search for extremely metal-poor stars in the Milky Way is traditionally conducted using existing methods that may not provide comprehensive or accurate results.
flip: By mimicking a Pristine narrow-band filter in the Gaia DR3 data, we can improve the search for these rare stars, providing a more accurate all-sky distribution of the metal-poor Milky Way and enhancing our understanding of galactic assembly and star formation histories.
title: Observational diagnostics of the old Milky Way using the most metal-poor stars

bit: The Galactic bulge region is typically avoided in the search for metal-poor stars due to the high density of mostly metal-rich stars and high dust extinction.
flip: The Galactic bulge region can be effectively studied for metal-poor stars, providing unique insights into the ancient Milky Way, by using metallicity-sensitive narrow-band CaHK photometry to identify metal-poor candidates.
title: Dynamical properties of ancient stars in the inner Milky Way with PIGS

bit: The conventional belief is that the properties of carbon-enhanced metal-poor (CEMP) stars are uniform across different Galactic environments.
flip: The innovative approach suggests that the properties of CEMP stars may vary between different Galactic environments, indicating differences in the early formation and chemical evolution of these environments.
title: On the frequency of carbon-enhanced very metal-poor stars
